2010 EAPSI China Project Outcomes Report

Ryan Overton, University of Tennessee

Host: Beijing Jiaotong University

 

            My research efforts while in China have been very successful. My host, Dr. Xuedong Yan, led the research efforts at the University of Tennessee’s Southeastern Transportation Center for several years before coming to Beijing. Therefore, I have worked with Dr. Yan for several years. With full intentions to conduct driver behavior research with Chinese participants, I was made aware that the driving simulator manufacturer delayed the shipment of the driving simulator to Jiaotong University from May 2010 to December 2010. Therefore, I brought my collected data from UT’s driving simulator research to China so Dr. Yan could advise me on the calculations and report.

            Embracing recent technological advances, transportation researchers are increasingly using driving simulators as an affordable means to collect driver behavior data through driving experiments. However, Simulator Adaptation Syndrome (SAS) prevails as the most significant factor for creating an uncomfortable environment for subjects, which may influence driving simulation effectiveness. Nearly every researcher addresses a warm-up period to allow drivers to adjust to the controls of the vehicle and minimize the effect of SAS. Nevertheless, few guidelines have been determined to ensure that drivers are acclimated to the vehicle controls and comfortable in the simulator environment. The purpose of this study is to identify key driving behavior indicators that would signify that subjects have become acclimated to the driving simulator system.

            From the categorical analysis, we revealed a few independent variables that may be used as indicators to researchers that subjects can or cannot feel comfortable to perform driving simulator experiments. High Risk SAS subjects are more likely to be identified as females and drivers over the age of 30. Low Risk SAS subjects are more likely to be identified as male and drivers under the age of 30. Videogame use can also serve as an indicator that subjects can be identified as Low Risk SAS. Identification of target subjects may serve useful to researchers who will require Low Risk SAS subjects for maneuver intensive testing including sharp, quick turns and scenarios with sever gradation changes.

            The driving performance variable mean comparisons in the discriminant analysis revealed a pattern of variables that proved significant in evaluating the adaptation of subjects. Accelerator pedal position, brake pedal position, and longitudinal acceleration are all valid measurement tools researchers can monitor to access the differences in warm-up driving behavior. Although the accelerator position, brake position, and longitudinal acceleration variables in this study were found to be the most significant reoccurring elements, further studies should be conducted to ensure accurate data collection by all researchers. The discriminant analysis function classification results for the four test locations revealed a noticeable trend in the distinction of driver’s performance.
